content.content:
## Talk track (fast)

- Start with **where DHW is big**: hotels, multifamily, healthcare, gyms, kitchens
- Quick wins: **recirc scheduling** + setpoint tune + insulation
- Upgrade path: **HPWH** (or centralized HPWH plants) + smart controls
- Bundle: DHW + HVAC electrification story (Scope 1 reduction)

**One-liner:** "We cut DHW costs with controls now‚Äîand electrify with 2‚Äì4√ó efficiency when you‚Äôre ready."

## What to verify (fast)

- Load profile: peak flow + daily gallons + occupancy
- Storage temperature, mixing valve strategy, and code constraints
- Recirc piping: balancing, return temp, pump control
- Space/air source for HPWH (mechanical room temp, ventilation)
- Electrical capacity and demand implications

**Rule:** quantify load + distribution losses; fix recirc controls before resizing equipment.

## What to look for on-site

- Water heater type: tank, tankless, boiler + HX, HPWH
- Venting: metal flue vs PVC (condensing), combustion air
- Setpoint on controller and presence of mixing/tempering valve
- Recirc pump: always-on? timer? aquastat? VFD?
- Any heat recovery: drainwater, condenser heat, laundry/process ties

sections.title: Introduction & Fundamentals
sections.subtitle: How DHW systems work and where savings live

content.content:
# Why Domestic Hot Water Matters

Domestic hot water (DHW) is the energy used to heat water for sinks, showers, kitchens, laundry, and sanitation.

DHW savings come from three levers:

1) **Reduce energy per gallon** (higher equipment efficiency)
2) **Reduce gallons used** (fixtures and behavior)
3) **Reduce distribution losses** (recirculation controls, pipe losses, and setpoints)

In many buildings, DHW is a quiet ‚Äúbase load‚Äù that runs year-round‚Äîmaking it a strong efficiency and electrification target.

content.quote: If your recirculation pump is running 24/7, you‚Äôre paying to heat the building‚Äôs plumbing. Fix controls and balancing before you buy new equipment.

content.content:
## Common DHW plant types

- **Storage tank water heaters** (gas or electric)
- **Boiler + indirect tank** (heat exchanger to storage)
- **Instantaneous / tankless** (gas or electric)

### Efficiency notes
- Standard gas storage is often ~0.60‚Äì0.70 UEF
- Condensing gas water heaters can reach ~0.90+ UEF (when return temps enable condensing)
- Electric resistance is ~1.0 COP but can be costly to operate

**Field tip:** venting tells a lot‚ÄîPVC venting typically indicates condensing equipment.

Sizing is about **peak** + **recovery**:

- Storage handles short peaks
- Recovery handles sustained loads

**Practical approach:** use meter/occupancy proxies (rooms, beds, units) to estimate daily gallons, then validate against bills where possible.

content.content:
## HPWH basics

A heat pump water heater uses a refrigeration cycle to move heat into the water.

- COP 2‚Äì4 typical (2‚Äì4√ó more heat per kWh than resistance)
- Best when the heat pump has a warm air source (mechanical room, outdoors, or a dedicated air path)

### Design considerations
- Space and airflow for heat pump units
- Condensate drain
- Noise and temperature impacts on mechanical rooms
- Electrical capacity and demand

**Sales translation:** HPWH delivers major operating savings and Scope 1 reductions, but needs a basic site viability check.

High peak with small storage can require backup

sections.title: Tankless / Instantaneous Systems
sections.subtitle: When they work and when they don‚Äôt

content.content:
## Tankless basics

- Heats water on demand; minimal storage losses
- Requires enough input power to meet peak flow

### Practical notes
- **Gas tankless** can work well where venting and gas capacity are available
- **Electric tankless** often has very high electrical demand and can be challenging for commercial retrofits

**Rule:** tankless is a fit for predictable, moderate peaks; for high peaks, storage + recovery is often simpler.

sections.title: Solar Thermal (Hot Water)
sections.subtitle: When solar hot water makes sense

content.content:
## Solar thermal overview

Solar thermal can preheat water before it enters the main plant.

Best fit:
- High, year-round DHW loads (hotels, laundries, pools)
- Adequate roof area and good solar resource

Watch-outs:
- Maintenance and controls complexity
- Integration and stagnation protection

**Sales translation:** solar thermal is niche but can be a strong story in the right load profile.

## Why recirc is often the biggest lever

Recirc keeps hot water near fixtures to reduce wait time. But if it runs continuously, it turns your piping into a radiator.

### Control strategies
- **Time schedules** (turn off at night/weekends)
- **Temperature (aquastat) control** (maintain a return temp band)
- **Demand control** (button/sensor triggers pump for short bursts)

### Field symptoms of waste
- Warm/hot return piping everywhere
- Pump running 24/7
- High return temperatures even during unoccupied hours

**Sales translation:** controls are low disruption and often pay back quickly.

cards.title: Insulate piping
cards.description: Uninsulated hot piping is pure loss. Prioritize long runs and mechanical rooms.

content.content:
## Common DHW heat recovery sources

- **HVAC condenser heat recovery** (chillers/VRF/heat pumps)
- **Refrigeration heat recovery** (grocery/process)
- **Laundry/process heat** (where applicable)
- **Drainwater heat recovery** (select facilities)

**Rule:** recovery works best when there is a steady heat source and steady DHW demand.

rows: Can provide preheat or full DHW in some seasons
Often strong match: refrigeration runs when DHW needed
Most effective with continuous showers and centralized drains
content.caption: Heat recovery fit guide

content.content:
## Control strategies that drive savings

- Align DHW setpoints to actual needs and code requirements
- Schedule recirc pumps and enable temperature bands
- Trend supply/return temperatures to detect drift
- Use alarms for stuck pumps/valves and abnormal temperatures

**Field tip:** if you can trend return temp overnight, you can often see wasted recirc instantly.

# Selling DHW Projects

## Positioning

- **Reliability**: hot water complaints are urgent; upgrades reduce risk
- **Controls-first**: immediate savings without customer disruption
- **Electrification**: HPWH reduces Scope 1 emissions and future-proofs

### Discovery questions
- What building type and occupancy patterns drive DHW?
- Any hot water complaints or long wait times?
- Is recirculation running continuously?
- What are gas and electric rates (and demand charges)?
- Any mandates for electrification / ESG reporting?

### Objection handling
| Objection | Response |
|---|---|
| "We can‚Äôt risk running out of hot water" | "We start with recirc tuning and add storage buffer‚Äîthen validate with a pilot." |
| "Electric is too expensive" | "HPWH is 2‚Äì4√ó efficient; we also check demand charges and load shifting." |
| "It‚Äôs a plumbing headache" | "We target high-value changes first: controls, insulation, balancing‚Äîminimal invasiveness." |

sections.title: Field Identification Guide
sections.subtitle: Identifying DHW equipment in the field

items: Photograph water heater(s): nameplate, model, year, input/output capacity
Note fuel type and venting (PVC vs metal, atmospheric vs power vent)
Capture controller setpoint and any mixing/tempering valve configuration
Trace recirc loop: pump location, control type (timer/aquastat/demand), and insulation
Record incoming cold water temperature proxy (climate/season) and any preheat source
Identify heat recovery connections (if any) and storage tank volumes
Ask about complaints: long waits, temperature swings, or outages

rows: Insulate long runs and mechanical rooms
content.caption: Fast field clues

# OBF Eligibility for DHW

On-Bill Financing typically supports DHW measures with hardware and measurable savings. Program rules vary by utility and segment.

questions.question: A heat pump water heater (HPWH) with COP 3.0 delivers how much heat per unit electricity compared to resistance heat?
questions.explanation: COP 3.0 means ~3 units of heat delivered per 1 unit electric input.

questions.question: What is a common major DHW energy loss in buildings with long piping runs?
questions.explanation: Recirculation loops can continuously lose heat through piping, especially when run 24/7.

questions.question: Which is typically the lowest-disruption ‚Äúquick win‚Äù for DHW energy savings?
questions.explanation: Recirc control changes can often cut losses quickly with minimal customer disruption.

questions.question: Why is a mixing (tempering) valve used in many DHW systems?
options: To allow higher storage temp while delivering safe fixture temp
questions.explanation: Mixing valves support safety and pathogen control while keeping delivered water at safe temperatures.

questions.explanation: Water heating energy depends on gallons heated and temperature rise; efficiency/COP converts to fuel input.
